titleInfo.title: Subspace Learning Approaches to Association Analysis for Multi-Modal Data

mods:mods.abstract: With the advent of tremendous and complex data sets, the accessibility of data has become easier than before. Data integration thus became a popular method to deal with multi-source data. Identifying a dynamic association among multi-modal data is practical in an explanatory data analysis (EDA) step. In this dissertation, we introduce statistical methods to tackle the issues in integrative analysis: blockwise missing imputation on the multi-modal data and dynamic association analysis. We elaborate on the approaches in the following chapters. First, we proposed a new envelope blockwise imputation (EBI) framework to address blockwise missing data in multiview data integration. Blockwise missing imputation is often needed as a preprocessing step for data integration. We develop a simultaneous envelope-based method that takes advantage of canonical correlations of different data sets to impute multiple missing blocks. The method effectively estimates canonical subspaces by fitting a regression model with congregating envelope subspaces, reducing the number of parameters in both predictors and responses. As a by-product, the envelope blockwise imputation method also obtains a more accurate estimate of the canonical correlations than the standard canonical correlation analysis (CCA). We devised an expectation conditional maximization (ECM) algorithm to estimate the envelope parameters. Next, we introduced a conditional cross-covariance reduction (CCR) model to study the dynamic association of two sets of random variables with a conditioned random variable. Sex dimorphism is crucial in various research fields, such as biomechanics and bioengineering. The difference in sex helps us understand certain musculoskeletal diseases, such as temporomandibular disorders (TMD). Especially, identifying an association between skull and temporomandibular joint muscles is essential to verify the sex difference in TMD. We collect data from 10 male and 11 female cadaver heads to study the dynamic associations between skull and muscle. The model identifies the most contrastive relationship between sex by selecting significant variables in skull measurement and temporomandibular joint muscle attachment. We apply a singular value decomposition-type algorithm via sparsity. In the analysis of the human cadaver data, we also introduce a permutation testing procedure to determine the number of variables selected. Finally, we briefly studied a basis spline transformation method to linearize the multivariate response and predictor under envelope assumptions. By incorporating the envelope parameters to the basis spline transformation, we numerically see that the correlation coefficients of response and predictor are leveraged.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Xin Zhang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hongyu Miao, University Representative; Elizabeth H. Slate, Committee Member; Wei Wu, Committee Member.
